Literature Review: Electrochemical additive manufacturing (ECAM) represents a cutting-edge approach to micro- and nanoscale fabrication, offering unparalleled precision and versatility. This review aims to provide a comprehensive introduction to the fundamental principles and recent advancements in ECAM, particularly focusing on techniques such as meniscus-confined electrodeposition (MCED), fluidic force microscopy (FluidFM), scanning ion conductance microscopy (SICM), and electrohydrodynamic redox printing (EHD-RP). The core principle of ECAM involves the controlled deposition of materials through electrochemical reactions, typically in a liquid electrolyte. This process allows for the creation of intricate three-dimensional (3D) structures with high resolution and accuracy. The ability to deposit a wide range of conductive materials, including metals, semiconductors, and polymers, makes ECAM particularly attractive for applications in microelectronics, sensing, and energy storage.
